awd_titl_txt: Layered Inorganic Solids as Building Blocks for Functional Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
DMR-1807116:  Layered Inorganic Solids as Building Blocks for Functional Materials


Non-Technical Summary

In 2004 the discovery of graphene, monolayer sheets of graphite building blocks, alerted the scientific community that two-dimensional (2D) materials can have radically different properties from chemically similar solids in which the bonding is three-dimensional. 2D materials have emerging applications in microelectronics, catalysis, lubrication, desalination of salt water, and many other areas. One of the challenges in the field is to develop gentle chemistry that can separate 2D sheets from each other without damaging them, and connect them to other materials through chemical bonds. This project, funded by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research at NSF, studies the fundamentals of these separation processes by measuring the energy of interactions between molecules, ions, and sheets of the major families of 2D materials:  both organic and inorganic in nature. The researchers also investigate chemical reactions that can transform one kind of 2D material into another. Education and outreach activities are part of the project by involving high school students and teachers in summer research programs.


Technical Summary

This project, funded by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research at NSF, investigates the reaction chemistry of two-dimensionally bonded materials. The research follows on the unexpected discovery of strong covalent interactions between late transition metal hydroxides and early transition metal oxide nanosheets. The principle investigator and his research group explore this effect with bi- and trimetallic complexes of late transition metals aiming to understand trends in chemical bonding that are relevant to interfacial materials properties such as adhesion, electronic contacts, and electrochemical energy storage. Isothermal titration calorimetry is used to measure the enthalpy and entropy of cluster adsorption from solution and to gain a deeper understanding of the intercalation, exfoliation, and restacking reactions of layered oxides and van der Waals solids (graphite, boron nitride, and layered metal chalcogenides). New layered oxysulfide and chalcogenide nanosheets are synthesized in order to explore the interactions of chalcophilic elements with their surfaces. Another aspect of the project is to develop selective surface chemistry for nanosheets derived from van der Waals solids, based on preliminary results obtained with coordinatively unsaturated organometallic complexes. Research on this project is integrated with mentoring and outreach activities that benefit students at the K-12 and undergraduate levels and that provide summer research experiences for high school teachers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The chemistry of layered materials which have strong chemical bonding in two dimensions and weak bonding in the third  is important in improving technologies that include rechargeable batteries, catalysis, and microelectronics.  This project has focused on developing a deeper understanding of the chemical reactivity of these inorganic lasagna materials. 

Nanosheets made by peeling apart layered inorganic solids (graphite, metal sulfides, metal oxides, and metal carbides) have been a source of fascination for the chemistry and physics communities because of new electronic properties and engineering applications that arise in two dimensions. In this project, the thermodynamic factors (energy and entropy changes) that control the chemical peeling of the layers was measured for the first time. Chemistries were developed, for different classes of layered materials, for gently pulling the layers apart without disrupting their in-plane chemical bonding. With this fundamental knowledge in hand, it was possible to design layered graphite oxide coatings that dramatically stabilize lithium metal during the multiple charging and discharging cycles of lithium ion batteries. This is a promising advance towards batteries thata have much higher charge capacity per unit weight for applications in portable electronics and electric vehicles. 

New chemistries were also devised for binding molecules selectively to the surfaces of the molecularly thin sheets. Theory and experiments were combined to measure and understand the energy of bonding between transition metal clusters and the surfaces of metal oxide sheets.  This information is fundamental to addressing the simple question of what sticks to what in the world of inorganic materials. It is important for designing more stable catalysts, and for understanding how the interfaces between dissimilar materials, such as metals and oxides, can be optimized for applications in microelectronic circuitry.  This research has resulted in the publication of four peer-reviewed papers with several more in the pipeline for publication.

 This project engaged graduate students, undergraduates, summer high school students, and high school teachers in interdisciplinary research that bridged topics in chemical synthesis and materials characterization.  Graduate and undergraduate students in this project participated in community outreach events and in the creation of content for remote science learning and engagement at the K-12 level.  Graduate students developed at-home experiments in materials chemistry, targeted at elementary and middle school students. This work was part of a long-running collaboration with the Franklin Institute (a science museum in Philadelphia) and the Penn State MRSEC.  Graduate students developed Slippery Solids, an experimental activity on layered materials, and Sunlight Oven about light-matter interactions, as part of the Mission: Materials Science series of videos produced by WPSU and the Penn State MRSEC.
